description: This table presents the word-level accuracy of the models evaluated on the test dataset.  The accuracy is reported to two decimal places (.2f). Results are broken down for three different cases: partial cases (texts with human and machine-generated portions), unchanged cases (purely machine-generated or human-written texts), and rewritten cases (texts where machine-generated portions have been rewritten).  The table shows the overall accuracy as well as the accuracy for each language individually.

caption: Table 6: Word level accuracy (.2f) of our models over our dataset (English)
description: This table presents the word-level accuracy of the models on the English subset of the dataset.  The accuracy is reported as a floating-point number with two decimal places. Each row represents a different language model, and the accuracy represents the model's performance in correctly identifying the authorship of individual words in the text samples.  The data shows the model's accuracy for each generator used to create the dataset's text samples.

caption: * excluding Chinese and Japanese
description: This table presents the word-level accuracy of the models on the test dataset for each language, broken down into three categories of text: partial cases (human-LLM co-authored texts), unchanged cases (texts entirely generated by LLMs), and rewritten cases (texts where human-authored segments were replaced with LLM-generated text).  The results exclude Chinese and Japanese, as character-level evaluations were used instead for those languages. The average accuracy across all three categories is also provided.

caption: Table 7: Prompts used in dataset creation : Partial cases
description: This table details the prompts used to generate the partially machine-generated texts in the dataset.  These prompts instructed the large language models (LLMs) to continue or rewrite a given text, resulting in texts with sections created by both humans and LLMs, thus simulating human-AI collaboration.

description: This table lists the prompts used to generate the 'rewritten' portion of the dataset.  These prompts instructed the large language models to produce a different version of the original text, such as an alternative phrasing, a later update, or a previous version.  The prompts were designed to simulate scenarios where human writers may revise or update their work, generating text that is partially machine-generated.

caption: Table 9: Training Hyper-parameters used
description: This table lists the hyperparameters used during the training of the multilingual longformer models.  It includes values for seed (for training and shuffling), number of epochs, batch size (both for training and evaluation), context length, learning rate, weight decay, and dropout rate for the CRF layer. These settings are crucial for reproducibility and understanding the training process of the models used in the paper's experiments.

It shows the accuracy of each model in identifying AI-generated text within three different scenarios: partially human-authored texts, unchanged (fully AI-generated) texts, and rewritten (human-edited AI-generated) texts.  The results are further categorized by language. This allows for an analysis of the model's effectiveness across various text types and languages, revealing its strengths and limitations in distinguishing AI-generated content under different conditions.
